Fixes faulty "PointerCancel" event registration in ListView.

Fixes faulty "PointerCancel" event registration in ListView.

WinJS ListView attempts to register for "PointerCancel" event, but only the "pointercancel" event is supported in all modern browsers, so the event never gets registered.
Today there is no direct impact from this bug, because the ListView relies on "PointerCancel" or "lostpointercapture" events to clean up UI state if a user on a touch device presses down on a listview item but then drags their finger to  scroll the listview items.
Yoday that user behavior will result in both "pointercancel" and "lostpointercapture" events being fired synchronously.
However, there is a proposed change that Chrome and Edge may move to implement where the "lostpointercapture" event may not fire because pointer capture will no longer be guaranteed to happen synchronously.
Once this change takes effect the ListView will no longer be guaranteed to recieve "lostpointercapture" events and will fail to clean up state correctly, unless this "pointercanel" event registration is fixed.

This is the initial commit of the _ElementResizeInstrument class which is intended to replace the IE11 native mselementresize event in our UI controls. Edge is removing the mselementresize and this new approach gives us a purely event driven javascript based solution that works in every browser we support, whereas mselementresize was only supported in IE11 and the current version of Edge.

-This change migrates the ListView, Pivot, and Hub controls to the _ElementResizeInstrument and removes their dependency on the "mselementresize" event.
-This change adds the forceLayout API to the Hub.
-Starting with this change, the Hub will only automatically detect size change events on the root ".win-hub" element. If developers programatically modify the size of the ".win-hub-surface" element or the size of the HubSection elements, they will need to call Hub.forceLayout() to notify the Hub that changes have occurred.
-Tests that used to only run in IE11 have been updated to expect automatic resize handling and run everywhere.

WinJS ViewBox, FlipView and SemanticZoom controls will be migrated to use _ElementResizeInstrument in the near future.

Improve ContentDialog's response to the InputPane

Fixes #1149 and #910

When the input pane shows, the ContentDialog's response was to maintain
its top/left position and to shrink its height as much as needed to avoid
being occluded by the input pane. This behavior resulted in a bug where,
if the dialog's top/left was close to the center of the screen, the dialog
could become very short when it resized to get out of the way of the input
pane (#1149).

To fix this, the new way the ContentDialog responds to the input pane is:
  - If the dialog will not be occluded by the input pane, then the dialog
    maintains its current size and position.
  - If the dialog will be occluded by the input pane, the dialog lays
    itself out using its normal layout rules but it does so in the
    unoccluded portion of the window (visible document) rather than in the
    whole window.

There was another bug (#910) where the ContentDialog would become
horizontally off center if the window was resized while the input pane was
showing. This is now fixed because the ContentDialog uses its normal
layout rules even when the input pane is showing.

Other changes:
  - Switiched from .focus() to .scrollIntoView() for keeping the focused
    element in view while resizing the dialog to get out of the input
    pane's way. The motivation for this change was that calling .focus()
    on document.activeElement no longer causes the element to scroll into
    view in Edge.
  - When the ContentDialog is shown, put focus on the root element of the
    dialog rather than on the first focusable element within the dialog's
    content area. The motivation for this change is that .scrollIntoView()
    is more aggressive about scrolling than .focus() was -- it scrolls the
    element to the top of its scroller even if that element was already in
    view. This results in a poor experience when showing the dialog and
    the first focusable element in the content area is a textfield -- the
    user will never have the chance to see the content at the top of the
    dialog because the dialog would immediately scroll it off screen.
    Order of events:
      - Dialog shows and puts focus on the first focusable element
        (assume it's a textfield) in the content area
      - Input pane shows
      - Dialog resizes
      - Dialog calls .scrollIntView() on the textfield to keep it in view
	during the resize thus scrolling the dialog's topmost content off
	the screen

This commit adds specialized knowledge to the control about when to show and hide the overflow button and updates the layout pass to accurately reflow commands based on whether or not overflow button has just claimed or released real estate from within the action area.

The logic to show/hide the overflow button was severely out of date, and did not take into account different closedDisplayModes or that commands in the BindingList could be hidden.

     and has been removed since was un documented and is no longer used. Anyone who may have been using it to determine whether or not the binding list was empty should instead check if
     (winControl.data.length > 0) on the their AppBar or ToolBar.

This commit also adds new unit tests and removes or updates many older tests and utilities geared around the appearance of the overflow button based on an out dated model, before the closedDisplayMode property was introduced.

Closes https://github.com/winjs/winjs/issues/1256

     This issue is that we were only adding Flyout's to the cascadingStack after we had confirmed that their animation had begun, but we were removing Flyouts to the cascade before they were guaranteed to be able to hide immediately.

     When a flyout is showing or hiding, its animation is uninterruptible, so calling hide() on a flyout that is showing, would result in the "hide" operation getting scheduled to be run again asynchronously after the show animation is complete.

     The flyout `_doNext` property tracks any behavior that should attempted after animations complete. It can only track one value so calling:

     flyout.show() // begins show animation, then adds flyout to the cascade.
     flyout.hide() // removes flyout from the cascade, can't interrupt show animation so queues to hide.
     flyout.show() // still can't interrupt original show animation, queues to show

     Results in a shown flyout with a `_doNext` value also of "show", which is just treated as a nop, so the flyout never gets added back to the cascading stack.

     The fix is to always append the flyout to the cascade when show() is called regardless if it is able to show immediately or has to be queued up to show. This matches the pattern for when he hide the flyout, and ensures that cascade always matches the latest state of what each flyout is doing or about to do, and is consistent with other existing patterns in the flyout code such as the "flyout.hidden" property getter which returns true if the flyout is either already in its hidden state, is animating to hidden state, or is queued to hide.

     The biggest challenge was to update the AppBar and ToolBar with a border when opened, without breaking existing styles for users who have migrated to 4.0. Rather than introducing a border that would eat up space in the ToolBar/AppBar content, we decided to introduce a border that overlays 1px of space on all sides of the actionarea and overflowarea elements.

     Listview uses a similar strategy for creating a border around selected elements without pushing the content or increasing the overall element size. Namely, create an element element with a transparent background and give it a solid border the border. Overlay the element completely over the element that you want to appear to give the appearance of having a border. The transparent element is given the CSS style "pointer-events: none" to prevent it from being a target for touch/mouse/pen interaction.

Fix #1202: Accent color sometimes not applied

Some times none of the accent color rules work because they are generated
with an accent color value of 'undefined'. This is due to a race condition
in the accent color code: sometimes the accent color rules are generated
before the accent color has been retrieved.

The fix makes accent color retrieval synchronous. In addition to fixing
this race condition, it also fixes an issue where the accent color could
flash in. If it took a while to reach DOMContentLoaded, the user would
initially see the page rendered without accent color and then after
DOMContentLoaded, they'd see the page rendered with accent color. This is
doesn't happen anymore beacuse color retrieval no longer waits on
DOMContentLoaded.

Task 911685:Overhaul cascading menu/flyout positioning logic to do smart positioning
Closes #994

 Previously Menu's have relied on the logic of placement "right" when cascading, meaning that each subMenu would appear to the right of the previous, regardless of the amount of available space on the right hand side or an RTL locale. This change contains the following changes to the cascading look and feel:

 - Tightened up the CSS to match the redlines, each new subMenu overlaps the previous by 4px subMenu, instead of the current implementation which had a 5px gap between each menu in the cascade.
 - The Cascade is RTL aware and prefers physical left instead of physical right when RTL is detected.
 - The horizontal placement logic has been updated to include 3 options when showing a new subMenu in the cascade:
 1. PREFERRED: When there is enough room to fit a subMenu on either side of the anchor,
 the subMenu prefers to go on the right hand side.
 2. FALLBACK: When there is only enough room to fit a subMenu on the left side of the anchor,
 the subMenu is placed to the left of the parent menu.
 3. LASTRESORT: When there is not enough room to fit a subMenu on either side of the anchor,
 the subMenu is pinned to the right edge of the window.
 - The vertical alignment logic has been updated to include 3 options when showing a new subMenu in the cascade:
 1. PREFERRED: When there is enough room to align a subMenu to either the top or the bottom of its anchor element,
 the subMenu prefers to be top aligned.
 2. FALLBACK: When there is enough room to bottom align a subMenu but not enough room to top align it,
 then the subMenu will align to the bottom of its anchor element.
 3. LASTRESORT: When there is not enough room to top align or bottom align the subMenu to its anchor,
 then the subMenu will center aligned to it's anchor's vertical midpoint.

Connect ContentDialog to LightDismissService

This is the last control that needed to be moved to the
LightDismissService. It's different in that all other controls are light
dismissable whereas this one is a modal (so many of the cues that cause a
light dismissable to dismiss (e.g. window blur, losing focus) do not cause
the ContentDialog to dismiss.

A bunch of functionality was moved from the ContentDialog into the
LightDismissService. What's nice is that you can concisely create a new
control which is a modal like this:

  this._dismissable = new _LightDismissService.ModalElement(
    element: this.element,
    tabIndex: -1,
    onLightDismiss: function () {
      this.hide();
    }.bind(this)
  );

Here's a summary of the changes:

ContentDialog
  - Edgy code was deleted because it's a deprecated feature.
  - ContentDialogManager was responsible for managing focus and
    coordination between dialogs. The LightDismissService now does this
    work.
  - Previously, you could only have 1 dialog shown at a time. Now, the
    LightDismissService enables you to show multiple dialogs at the same
    time. This also happens to fix #944.
  - These things were deleted because they're now handled by the
    LightDismissService:
    - Back click (hardware back button on phone)
    - beforeRequestingFocusOnKeyboardInput (type to search)
    - Focus handler for tracking and restoring focus
    - Key handlers which ensure that keyboard events don't escape the
      ContentDialog (for example, so you can't trigger the
      WinJS.UI.BackButton with a hotkey while the dialog is open)

LightDismissService
  - Edgy code was deleted because it's a deprecated feature.
  - Right-clicking on click eater now triggers a dismiss. Previously, it
    didn't because right-click triggered edgy (but now edgy is
    deprecated).
  - Added a LightDismissalPolicy for modals which describes which light
    dismiss cues should cause a modal to dismiss (only escape and hardware
    back button on phone)
  - ILightDismissable onActivate
    - Renamed to onTakeFocus because it was always used as a cue to for
      the dismissable to take focus when it became the active dismissable.
      However, we renamed it because we'd like to call it in one
      additional scenario: when the topmost dismissable loses focus but
      refuses to dismiss.
  - Added ILightDismissable onShow which gets called when a light
    dismissable gets put into the LightDismissService (i.e. calls
    LightDismissService.shown)
  - tryFocus was moved to _ElementUtilities._tryFocusOnAnyElement so other
    files can use it.
  - Added ModalElement which provides an implementation of
    ILightDismissable for modals. Much of its code was the same as
    LightDismissableElement so the common code was factored into
    AbstractDismissableElement and they both inherit from it.
  - A bunch of code for overriding default implementations of functions in
    LightDismissableElement/AbstractDismissableElement was deleted because
    it was just noise. In practice, only 4 things are ever overriden:
    element, tabIndex, onLightDismiss, and onTakeFocus.
  - Incorporated type to search handling
    (beforerequestingfocusonkeyboardinput) into LightDismissService. When
    any dismissable is shown, type to search it suppressed.
  - Propagating keyboard events in the light dismiss stack. When a modal
    is shown, we don't want key events to escape the modal and be seen by
    the body (e.g. hotkey for triggering WinJS.UI.BackButton). Imagine if
    a Flyout is shown by a ContentDialog. We still don't want the hotkeys
    to propagate. But the Flyout and ContentDialog are siblings in the DOM
    so the ContentDialog won't have the opportunity to eat the key events.
    We solve this by having all light dismissables send their key events
    to the LightDismissService and the service will send them to all
    dismissables so they'll all have the opportunity to handle them.
    Implementation-wise, this was done by
      - Adding keyDown, keyUp, and keyPress to the service. Light
	dismissables should call these when a key event occurs within
	them.
      - Adding onKeyInStack to ILightDismissable. The LightDismissService
	calls this on each dismissable when its propagating a key event
	down the light dismiss stack.

Flyout.js
  - Had to update _LightDismissableLayer because it is an
    ILightDismissable and we modified the ILightDismissable interface.

Switch to new localization scheme #1101

First of all, it's important to note that the WinJS localization
infrastructure may search for localized strings in several ways:
  1a. WinRT. When WinRT is available, it asks it for localized strings.
  1b. window.strings. When WinRT is not available, WinJS looks up
      localized strings on a global variable called "strings". WinJS
      publishes on "strings" thru a file called js/en-US/ui.strings.js
      which is included in the WinJS build.
  2. When (1) fails, WinJS falls back to english strings which ship with
     WinJS (provided by base.js).

Here's a summary of this commit:
- manifest.resjson was deleted because it didn't appear to be used
  anywhere. It seems to be an artifact of the framework package.
- WinJS localized string path changed:
  - old: ms-resource://Microsoft.WinJS.4.0/ui/<someStringName>
  - new: ms-resource:///Microsoft.WinJS/ui/<someStringName>
  It didn't seem important to include the version number and it was easier
  to implement. Also, we need an extra slash at the beginning of the path
  because we're no longer a framework package.
- During the build, the localized strings are emitted in a separate
  directory called "Microsoft.WinJS.4.0-strings". This directory looks
  like this:
    Microsoft.WinJS.4.0-strings
      en-us
        Microsoft.WinJS.resjson
      de-de
        Microsoft.WinJS.resjson
      etc.
  Apps interested in being localized should include this directory in
  their VS project and remove any languages they are not interested in.
- Strings in resjson files must now be prefixed with "ui/". The framework
  package used to use namespacing to put stuff under "ui/". Because we're
  no longer a framework package, we can't take adavantage of official
  namespaceing so we prefix the WinJS strings with "ui/" to simulate
  namespacing.
- Consolidate to 1 english resjson file. Before we stored the english
  strings in several places and it was easy for them to fall out of sync:
  - src/js/en-US/ui.resjson
  - src/strings/EN-US/ui.json
  - src/strings/EN-US/appBarIcons.json

  The first one was used to produce ui.strings.js. It was also included in
  base.js as the source of the fall back english strings.

  The latter two weren't actually used yet. The plan was to feed them to
  WinRT along with all of the other languages in the "src/strings" folder.

  As of this commit, we only have a single english strings file
  (src/strings/en-us/Microsoft.WinJS.resjson) which serves all
  of the purposes (localization with WinRT, localization without WinRT,
  and english fallback strings that ship with WinJS).

Fix #1081: ListView layout doesn't clean up envInfo

After disposing a ListView, when attempting to reuse its layout with a new
ListView, the new ListView doesn't render properly. Repros in browsers that
don't support CSS grid.

Here's a description of the problem and fix. Layouts can be reused. They
have 2 lifecycle methods: initialize and uninitialize. The problem here is
that the layout isn't properly cleaning up some state during uninitialize.
Specifically:
  - The layout should clear its envInfo.
  - The layout should remove the win-nocssgrid class from the surface

The former point is causing the symptom. The layout adds the win-nocssgrid
class to the ListView when it calculates envInfo but in the new ListView,
it already has envInfo so it never adds win-nocssgrid to it causing it to
render incorrectly.

Move Overlay-based dismissables to LightDismissService

In the past, all light dismissables derived from Overlay and Overlay
implemented all of the light dismiss logic. This model wasn't extensible
(i.e. it was hard to implement new light dismissables) so we created
LightDismissService which reimplements the light dismiss logic. This
change deletes the Overlay's light dismiss logic and connects the
Overlay-based light dismissables to the LightDismissService.

Here's the inheritance hierarchy for Overlay-based light dismissables:

- Overlay
  - Flyout
    - Menu
  - SettingsFlyout
  - LegacyAppBar

Here's a more detailed overview of the change:

With the LightDismissService, light dismissables are expected to take
focus before playing their show animation (by calling
LightDismissService.shown which will call onActivate) and they are
expected to relinquish focus at the end of their hide animation (by
calling LightDismissService.hidden which will call onActivate).

For a small example of connecting a control to the LightDismissService see
https://github.com/winjs/winjs/commit/be18db88ba2671257a6eab8dbba9286d200fe37b#diff-e9b46fea8fd9a25e479171eaa0fd77ad.

_Overlay.js
  - Deleted escape key handler because it now gets handled by the
    CascadeManager (Flyout.js).
  - Replace _endHide with _beforeEndHide. They are called at slightly
    different times (the latter after the element is invisible while the
    former is called before it's invisible) but they work equally well for
    our purpose.
  - Doesn't need to connect to LightDismissService because subclasses are
    responsible for that.
- SettingsFlyout.js
  - Deleted old light dismiss code
  - Connected to LightDismissService
  - SettingsFlyout now takes focus at the start of its show animation
    rather than at the end of it.
- LegacyAppBar.js
  - Deleted old light dismiss code
  - Connected to LightDismissService
  - Deleted AppBar coordination code. In Win 8 and 8.1, users used to be
    able to open and interact with multiple AppBars at the same time. The
    design has changed such that if multiple AppBars are open, you can
    only interact with the topmost one. All of the code for coordinating
    multiple AppBars was deleted because it's no longer needed and its
    existence was making connecting the AppBar to the LightDismissService
    more complicated.
- Flyout.js
  - Deleted old light dismiss code
  - Connected to LightDismissService
  - This was the most complicated Overlay to connect to the
    LightDismissService because you can have multiple Flyouts open
    simultaneously all above the click eater. This is what enables
    cascading menus. _LightDismissableLayer does most of the work of
    connecting to the LightDismissService.
- _LightDismissService.ts
  - Deleted requiresClickEater and OrderedCache. These were created for
    supporting sticky AppBar but we no longer need this code because
    sticky AppBar no longer exists.
  - Added getZIndexCount. This enables a light dismissable to have
    multiple z-indices allocated to it. It's used by Flyout.js for
    supporting cascading menus.
  - Use tryFocus helper instead of _ElementUtilities._tryFocus. The former
    is now used instead of the latter so that we can give focus to
    elements with a tabIndex of -1.
  - Added restoreFocus to LightDismissableElement which dismissables can
    make use of when overriding onActivate.
  - Added updated method. This enables dismissables to notify the
    LightDismissService when their getZIndexCount function is going to
    start returning a different value.

Tests
  - Changed
    "testShowAndHideMovesFocusWithoutWaitingForAnimationToComplete" to
    "testShowMovesFocusSyncAndHideMovesFocusAsync". As mentioned earlier
    in this commit message, show still moves focus before the animation
    but hide now moves focus after the animation.
  - "checkShouldBeTabStop" was breaking tests because it calls blur/focus
    which causes focus events in the middle of the tests which sometimes
    caused light dismissables to dismiss. Switched "checkShouldBeTabStop"

  - "testBackClickEvent" was tricky because Application.stop kills all

ListView: Cross-browser method for hiding scrollbar

During ListView's entrance/exit animation, we don't want to animate the
scrollbar. We solve this differently in different browsers:
  - IE: Animate the win-viewport and hide scrollbar with
    -ms-overflow-style:none (so that the scrollbar isn't animated).
  - Other browsers: Instead of hiding the scrollbar, we animate
    win-surface so that the scrollbar is visible but doesn't move.

The technique of animating win-surface causes a bug where items may be
positioned incorrectly because during the entrance/exit animation,
win-surface becomes the offsetParent of the win-containers. The ListView
is written under the assumption that win-viewport will always be the
offsetParent of the win-containers.

Specifically, this can be triggered by editing the ListView while it's
still playing its entrance animation so that the entrance animation and
editing animations are played at the same time. The repro from
https://github.com/winjs/winjs/issues/146#issuecomment-41634154 triggers
this.

To fix this, all browsers now:
  - Play the entrance/exit animation on win-viewport
  - Hide the scrollbar during the animation by setting overflow:hidden on
    win-viewport.

This change doesn't cause a measurable change in performance during the
entrance/exit animations.

Fix #146: Replace data during lazy container creation

A "Container missing after updateContainers" exception was thrown in the
following app scenario:
  - ListView is initialized with local data and a fetch is made to get the
    latest data from the server.
  - While the ListView is lazily creating containers, the server responds.
    The app replaces the local data in the ListView's data source with the
    data from the server. Specifically, this can be done by setting the
    Binding.List's length to 0 and pushing on the data from the server.

The problem was that the container creation set a cap at the current
number of containers + the change in the data source count. When doing a
direct replacement of the Binding.List's data, the count doesn't change so
updateContainers doesn't create any new containers. However, it receives a
number of notifications for items it hasn't created containers for yet
(because lazy container creation was still in progress). These items
require containers for animations. Because these items don't get
containers, the exception gets thrown.

The fix is to set the container creation cap at the current number of
containers + the number of inserted notifications we received (when lazy
container creation is in progress). This will ensure that updateContainers
creates enough containers for the animations.

Fix #891: ListView items sometimes jump during animations

At the start and end of editing animations, itemsblocks jump by the amount
of the win-container's top margin. The bug is due to the win-container's
top margin collapsing thru the win-itemcontainer during animations.
This margin collapsing only occurs during animations (due to
win-itemscontainer switching between overflow:hidden and visible). Whether
or not the margin collapsing is happening affects the size of the
win-itemscontainer which is what causes the jumping.

The fix is to prevent the margin collapsing from happening during
animations. The win-itemscontainer-padder prevents the margin collapsing
as long as it isn't display:none. Instead of styling display:none, we now
style height and width to 0. Consequently, win-itemscontainer-padder
prevents margin collapsing without taking up any space.

Most of the change was to update the tests to catch this bug. The
animation tests would have caught this bug if they verified the animation
state of a greater number of items. The changes included:
  - Verifying the size and position of all visible items (instead of just
    the deleted item)
  - Extending the height and width of the ListView so that more items fit
    on the screen.
  - Decreasing the number of items per group so that more groups fit on the
    screen.
  - Instead of making the deleted item the first or last element on the
    screen, put it closer to the middle of the screen so that there will
    be some items above it and some items below it that need to be
    animated.
  - Styling win-container's margin-top instead of margin-bottom (this is
    what we recommend to apps to avoid margin collapsing in vertical
    ListLayout).
  - Updated styling of win-itemscontainer's margins to reflect the fact
    that the defaults are never -200px anymore.

Force light dismissables to have a tabIndex

Every light dismissable should have a tabIndex on its root element. Here's
why. When clicking on a non-focusable element, the browser will move focus
to the first focusable ancestor. If none of the ancestors has focus, then
the browser will move focus to the body. Because focus has moved outside
of the light dismissable, it will dismiss. To prevent this undesirable
behavior, every light dismissable should have a tabIndex on its root
element.

Fix #637

This changes the behavior of WinJS.UI.Pages.render() so that the promise returned is the final promise chain constructed by the Page control.

Previously there was an issue of the render complete promise forking to call parentedPromise and Page.render(), so any issues during loading would propagate down that path as well and result in unhandled errors ending up in Application.onerror (triggering App termination) unless the developer added a custom Page.error() handler for each Page since the default error handler will blindly rethrow the error.

This means that functions chaining off Pages.render() will now get fired after ready has been called. It also means that in the navigation template specifying an invalid page to navigate to will no longer result in an app crash since all errors are handled by the cleanup() function.

Fix ContentDialog dispose

Disposing a hidden ContentDialog would lead to an exception which would
cause the app to terminate.

Here's why. When disposing a hidden dialog, the dialog would put the show
promise into an error state. Because the dialog wasn't showing, nobody
outside of the dialog would have a reference to the show promise so nobody
could handle the error promise. Thus, the promise error would remain
unhandled and lead to app termination.

The fix is to only create the show promise when somebody asks for it by
calling the show() function.

To catch this kind of mistake in the tests, added initUnhandledErrors and
validateUnhandledErrors to all of the ContentDialog tests.

Also, removed overflow:hidden from the dialog's title so that low hanging
letters don't get clipped (clipping used to be needed when we wanted to
limit the number of lines of text in the title).

Fix #253: Hub: Fix scroll position restoration

When using a horizontal Hub, it is best practice to specify all section
widths in CSS for performance reasons.

However, developers may choose to have a section whose width depends on
its content. In this case, the section may change width during
WinJS.UI.processAll (e.g. if the section contains a Repeater). In this
scenario, to reliably restore a scroll position after a navigation, the
developer should wait for the Hub to fire loadingState=complete.

The bug was setting scrollPosition in loadingState=complete didn't work
because the Hub had the sizes of the sections before they were processed
rather than afterwards (so it would clamp the desired scroll position
incorrectly).

The fix is for the Hub to invalidate its measurements before firing
loadingState=complete if a section changed size during processing.

In IE "focus" and "blur" event listeners fire asynchronously. "focusin" and "focusout" fire synchronously. In other browsers "focus", "blur", and "focusout/focusin(where available)" all fire synchronously.
Because Firefox doesn't support "focusin" and "focusout" natively, our _ElementUtilities._addEventListener WinJS code today will fire synthetic "focusin" & "focusout".

Because we anchor these to the native focus and blur events, we fire our synthetic events asynchronously in IE and syncronously in every other browser. This change has us anchor our synthetic events to the native "focusin" and "focusout" where its supported (everywhere but firefox), otherwise "focus" and "blur".  The net effect is that we should get synchronous synthetic "focusin" and "focusout" events for every browser we support.

Fix #683: SplitView: Position relative descendants

Currently, if you put an element with position: relative/absolute inside
of the SplitView's content, this element will end up being rendered on top

putting a SearchBox inside of the SplitView's content.

  2. The pane element is always rendered on top of the content element.

Title: Update List and Grid layouts to use one giant structural node when/if we detect flexbox bugs in the enviornment, in order to enable cross browser support of item striping after edits.

We have changed the scope of item striping to only apply to WinJS list and grid layouts as well as any custom layouts that opt in to using structural nodes by setting Layout.numberOfItemsPerItemsBlock. This checkin changes our List and Grid Layouts behavior when we detect known bugs with nested flexbox scenarios in the browsing enviornment to always use structural nodes, so that those layouts can continue to reparent items into containers whenever edits happen, with reparenting being the prerequisite to preserving item striping after edits without compromising performance.

Normally our List and Grid layouts will put all of the items of a group into several win-itemblocks elements with, each itemsblock containing a handful of items. The itemsblocks are in turn put into a  single win-itemscontainer element which contains all the itemsblocks and items for that group.  Our List and Grid layouts will then make both the itemscontainer element and the itemsblocks elements display:flex.

However some browsers do not display nested flex boxes correctly, and has a result, our layouts when detecting these bugs exists, have had been forgoing itemsblocks entirely, putting all of the win-items directly into the win-itemscontainer, leaving the win-itemscontainer as the only display:flex element.  With this change we now handle bugs with nested flexboxes by putting one giant itemsblock into the itemscontainer element, putting all of the win-items of a group into the single itemsblock, making the itemscontainer display:block, and let the itemsblock element be the display:flex element.

ListView panning updates for iOS, Fixes #205

The root cause of the panning performance issues we see in iOS is that we don't get scroll events/or an accurate scroll values while there is inertia, so our virtualization code does not know what items to realize.

We evaluated different options:
-Do nothing
-Remove inertia (by stop setting -webkit-overflow-scroll: touch)
-Fake scrolling with translate and animations. We evaluated two libraries (1) iScroll: winjs-ebang.azurewebsites.net/iscroll/listview.html 2) Scrollability: http://winjs-ebang.azurewebsites.net/scrollability/listview.html, and it look "good/ok" on an iPad Air, but not so well on an iPhone 4s (which is still supported for iOS 8)
-Use larger prefetch buffer: a) no virtualization b) larger front buffer

We decided to go with the last option. This change introduces two private flags that allow us to configure the number of pages ahead/behind the scrolling direction that we want to prefetch. It is currently enabled only in iOS, and the default values are 2 behind, 6 ahead of the panning direction.

You can play with the values of these flags here: http://winjs-ebang.azurewebsites.net/lvlistlayout.html

Before:
http://winjs-ebang.azurewebsites.net/lvlistlayout-prehover.html

After:
http://winjs-ebang.azurewebsites.net/lvlistlayout.html

Demo: http://1drv.ms/1pD0F6T

Note: iOS still allows you to scroll huge amount of pixels (thousands), in those cases, we will still see backdrops (the only option would be huge prefetch buffers which would have memory implications). Fix CSS grid feature detection in tests #416

Cell spanning tests were running in Safari despite it not supporting CSS
grid. The problem is that Safari CSSStyleDeclarations have a property for
grid-column (specifically, -webkit-grid-column) despite the CSS engine
ignoring such attributes.

(checking for the existence of -ms-grid-row). This means that ListView
will only use CSS grid in IE. This is probably what we want because the
ListView's use of CSS grid is based on IE 10/11's implementation. If other
browsers were to implement CSS grid, ListView would have be updated anyway
to make use of the latest CSS grid standard.

Fix #127: Get Tooltip tests running in all browsers

Most of the problems stemmed from WWA/IE implementing pointer events while
other browsers implement touch events. The only touch events that seem to
be implemented consistently are:
  - touchstart
  - touchend
  - touchmove

Tooltip relies on pointerover and pointerout for:
  - Showing a tooltip when the user presses and holds on a tooltip element
  - Showing a tooltip when the user hovers their finger onto a tooltip
    element
  - Hiding a tooltip when the user hovers their finger off of a tooltip
    element

There aren't any touch event equivalents for pointerover or pointerout. So
the first scenario was achieved in other browsers by also having
pointerdown (touchstart) show a tooltip. There isn't a good way to
implement the other 2 scenarios without pointerover/out so the other 2
scenarios do not work in other browsers. We are okay with this.

The unit tests which fired pointerover/out had to be modified to fire
alternative events in browsers that don't have pointer events.

--

When a tooltip is triggered, the control notes which input method
triggered the tooltip (_showTrigger). Before this change, when multiple
input methods triggered a tooltip, the control remembered the last method.
This was changed slightly so that it remembers the first method instead.

--

Our translation table used touchleave as the touch equivalent of
pointerout. Because touchleave has different semantics than pointerout and
nobody is currently relying on pointerout mapping to touchleave,
pointerout no longer maps to touchleave. When somebody needs pointerout,
we can think more about the appropriate touch equivalent.

--

Most of the other changes were around adjusting the unit test assertions
to account for slight differences in the return values of the CSS APIs of
the browsers.
Replace usage of DOMNodeInserted in Rating with a node-inserted css animation event (more reliable). Closes #298.

Fix #136: NavBar: Fix resize tests

Tests were failing in browsers that don't support mselementresize.

Developers who resize a NavBar element should call forceLayout on it so
the resize is detected in browsers which do not support mselementresize.

NavBar also resizes when the window is resized in all browsers.

So the resize tests were updated as follows:
  - If the browser supports mselementresize, we do nothing other than
    resize the element. Otherwise, we fire a window resize event.
  - Each resize test was duplicated to call forceLayout after changing the
    element's size. These tests run in all browsers. They test the scenario
    that the developer wants to change the size of the NavBar without
    changing the size of the window.

Fix #136: Fix setting of focus when NavBar appears

When the NavBar is shown, focus was being set onbeforeshow. At this time,
the NavBar's visibility is hidden and some browsers do not allow hidden
elements to receive focus. This was fixed by setting focus onaftershow.

Fix #136: Fix focus issues in tests

NavBarContainer had to be given an explicit tabIndex of -1 otherwise it
wouldn't be able to receive focus in most browsers.

Many of the tests checked that the NavBarContainer received focus
immediately after calling .focus on it. This was removed beacuse:

    quickly moved to a command within the NavBar. Each test already
    verified that the command received focus a little later so this check

Fix #214: NavBar: currentIndex doesn't always work

When both currentIndex and maxRows are set in the NavBar's constructor,
currentIndex is usually ignored.

The problem is that after the NavBar measures, it sets the height of the
surface which triggers the resize handler. The resize handler sets
currentIndex to 0 thus overriding the value that was passed into the
constructor.

The fix is to only run the resize handler when the NavBar's size really
did change.

Additionally, the NavBarContainer's focus state (including focus,
currentIndex, and scroll position) should be reset when the NavBar is
hidden and then reshown. The NavBarContainer used to fulfill this
requirement indirectly thru its resize handler (the resize handler is
triggered when when the NavBar goes from display="none" to "block"). Now
that the NavBarContainer's resize handler only runs if its viewport's size
has changed since the last measure, we need a more explicit way to reset
the focus state when the NavBar is hidden and then reshown. This
requirement is now fulfilled by calling closeSplitAndReset when NavBar
fires its beforeshow event.

Fix AppBar cross browser unit test "KeyboardingInEmptyAppBar" failure. This is one of the unit tests referenced in #117   that is failing cross browser. When an AppBar is opened, the AppBar moves focus to the first AppBar command in DOM Order, however if the AppBar is empty, it focuses itself.

According to the HTML5 spec, DIV's with no tabIndex set should not be focusable through tabbing, pointerDown, or the element.focus() API. However, in IE a DIV with no tabIndex is able to be focused by pointerDown or the element.focus() API.
Other modern browsers seem to get the behavior in the spec correct, so in those browsers the AppBar is not able to focus itself because since no tabIndex is set, and this unit test fails.

The fix is to check if the user has specified a tabIndex on the element already during the AppBar constructor. If they have not, we explicitly set a tabIndex of -1, which means that an element is not focusable through tabbing, but is focusable through pointerDown and the element.focus() API.

Move to custom focusin and focusout events

All blur/focusout and focus/focusin events were replaced with custom WinJS
events by registering via WinJS.Utilities._addEventListener for focusout
and focusin, respectively. These custom events bring IE's native
focusout/focusin behavior to other browsers. Specifically:
  1. They ensure that document.activeElement is set appropriately within
     focusout handlers. In Chrome's native focusout,
     document.activeElement is always BODY which isn't very useful.
  2. They work in Firefox even though it doesn't support focusin/focusout
     natively.
  3. They allow handlers to determine who lost focus and who is gaining
     focus. Native blur/focus only provide half of this information.

Also, we have some code in the unit tests which generates keyboard events.
It generates UIEvents but the keyCode property of a UIEvent is not
settable in Chrome. To fix this, switched to CustomEvent so that we can
override the keyCode property.

Move to cross browser setImmediate

setImmediate doesn't exist in other browsers. Generally, we use setTimeout
0 as a fallback. In the case of the scheduler, we use setTimeout 16 as a
fallback since the goal is to give the host the opportunity to complete
some work.

The reasons for the use of setImmediates can be divided into a few
categories. They are given different names so that we can tweak the
implementations as needed:
  1. Yield for events. Allows the browser to finish dispatching its
     current set of events before running the callback.
  2. Yield for DOM modifications. Allows the browser to notice a DOM
     modification before running the callback.
  3. Move to the scheduler. Some setImmediates didn't have a reason for
     using it and so were moved to the scheduler:
     - Lazily clean up DOM weak reference table.
     - The ItemContainer schedules some work to give the caller of the
       constructor the opportunity to synchronously put the control into
       the DOM.
     - The Pivot schedules some work to avoid re-entrancy.
  4. The rest didn't fit into a category and use a generic _setImmediate
     helper.
